div.p: 1. V. Monday.

William Spear came for me at ten O’Clock this morning, and I went with him to the Railway-House, and thence walked to the Stone quarries. Mr Leeds had agreed with my Son Charles to come out from Boston, and look at them, with a view to ascertain what price I should ask for my quarry lands—we went to the ledges now hired by Dudley and by Winkley, the former of which have been successful, but the latter have at least the prospect of failing— I found the rock on the top of which was drilled last Summer the hole marking the boundary between my ground and the wigwam ledge—but so much of the rock has since been taken away that the aspect of the whole region has changed— The Tower too which was heretofore a land mark was last February taken away— The quantities, of rocks removed from day to day rapidly change the face of the Country itself, and a village of houses is growing up in the wilderness— I expect they will soon seek incorporation as a Town to be set off from Quincy— As we were returning home after noon, we met opposite to Mr T. Greenleaf’s Mr Leeds and his brother in a Carryall, who had just come out from Boston and called at my house— He said he had been belated by sickness in his family. We turned back again and went to the ledge, North and east of the wigwam quarry— This he viewed, and we pointed out to him the direction of the Borland and Savile joint lot. He said
he had a brother at New-York, who wished to form a company, for working some of the Stone-quarries here, and it was for him that he was making the enquiries, respecting the price at which the Lands might be obtained— He asked me therefore to fix a price, which I would take, for one or for the three lots— I told him I should ask for the Field lot containing about sixteen Acres, ten thousand dollars— He asked if I would not take for it 500 dollars an Acre— I said no—but for the three lots containing in all from 47 to 50 Acres, I would take in cash 500 dollars an acre. I said that speaking from recollection, I might not be accurate as to the quantity of Land in each of the Lots—but I believed the plans of them all were at my Sons office in Boston, where he said he would call to-morrow and inspect them— I promised also to allow 30 days for the consideration of the demand of 500 dollars an acre for the 50 acres, and 60 days for the offer of the sixteen Acres for 10000 dollars— We then parted and I got home just before two o’Clock— After dinner we had a visit from Mr and Mrs Frothingham who took tea with us. Mr Frothingham mentioned an incident which had occurred this day in Boston, and produced much excitement— Two coloured women from Baltimore claimed as Slaves—brought by Habeas Corpus, before Chief Justice Shaw—declared by him not to be detainable; and before his Sentence was declared, hurried out of the Courthouse, by a number of coloured people upon a threat from the agent of the claimant, that he would at all events detain them— The women were conveyed out of the Jurisdiction of the County and were not brought back into the Court.
2. IV. Tuesday.

I discovered this morning at the edge of my seminary next to the gate a plumelet about one inch out of the ground, up since yesterday morning and parted at the top; a hickory walnut, the growth of which I propose to observe— About ten days since I first observed another at the corner of the bed, which is now four inches high, and has opened one collateral stalk with three oval leaves, another just over it with one leaf and a stalk diverging from the top with three oval leaves, all dark brown— I discovered also at the eastern end of the bed, three leaves of a currant bush—the only one from the multitude of currant seeds which I planted last Summer. Henry Hardwick was here, and agreed to give fifty dollars for the small strip of Salt-marsh land about which he has been in treaty with me several years, and which I viewed with him last Summer— He wants the Deed which I promised to draw, and deliver to him in the course of a few days— Harvey Field also called upon me, and spoke of several Subjects of interest to the town of Quincy to himself, and to my personal and private affairs— He is now for the second year a member of the Legislature of the State, and has succeeded in obtaining a Charter for a Bank in this Town, by the name of the Quincy Stone Bank, with a Capital of one hundred thousand dollars, of which he is one of the directors— The bank commenced its operations on the first of June last with half its capital paid in, and notice is already given for the payment of the second instalment of fifty per Cent, on or before the 15th. of this month— My Son Charles took twenty shares of the Stock of this Bank for me, and ten shares for himself— Mr Field said they were using some temporary plates for their Bills—but that in about two months they would have their new plates with the head of my father engraved on one side, and that of John Hancock on the other— As they were both natives of Quincy, I thought they would form a very suitable devise for the Bills.— Field is a very enterprizing man, and engages perhaps in too many venturous Speculations at once— He has purchased of John Fowle, the House and Land that was James Bracketts at the Corner of the road opposite the episcopal church. Fowle had bought them of Brackett or his legal Representatives.— Rather Field purchased
of the Brackett’s and sold to Fowle for 3425 dollars—of which Fowle paid in cash 1425 dollars, and gave a note and mortgage for 2000 dollars with a Policy of Insurance upon the buildings— Field wishes to raise money upon the mortgage and proposed to assign it to me. I promised him an answer in a few days— His father Joseph Field died last Winter, at the age of eighty-four— My Son Charles came out from Boston, with his wife, and their infant Son Charles and his Nurse to spend with us a few weeks of the Summer— Mr. E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and budded for me two more cherry trees in my garden. There are now twelve of this year, and four of the last year which have taken— My writing was again this day very deficient.
3. III:30. Wednesday.

I found another hickory seedling in my Seminary with a stem four inches high, opening in a triangle of three stalks with leaves yet unformed. It has been a week or more out of the ground—also two fresh seedling plums, one in the seminary; the other in the garden of the last year and a different plum— I watered the box next to the road in front of the South-east corner of the house— The seedling Plants in the boxes and Pots perish unless sheltered from the Sun and watered— The patches also succeed extremely well, but require sheltering and watering the first Season— Charles went to Boston this morning and returned to dinner— Mr Solomon Lincoln from Hingham was here this afternoon, and paid me three dollars for the recording at the Patent Office the assignment of Charles Lane’s patent— Mr Lincoln had some conversation with me upon present politics which are not very satisfactory. The object of chief concernment is the Presidential Election, which I deem of very inferior importance to others concerning which the public mind is neither animated nor sound— Mr Lincoln is of those who incline to adhere to Webster without indulging a particle of hope of his success— They are to have a whig Convention at Worcester in September to settle their definitive whig policy— Mr R. L. Porter the Editor of the American Traveller a weekly Boston Newspaper was also here, but I did not see him— I read much in the Journals of the old Congress, to recover the memory of their proceedings upon subjects of France— I perplexed and entangled myself, but wrote very little— The public debt, the public Lands the regulation of Commerce, and the intercourse with Indians were the gordian knots of the confederacy— In the solution of them all, James Madison took a conspicuous and leading part; but how his agency is to be set forth in the form of an Eulogy, doing entire justice to him and no injustice to others; this is the task before me, and it oppresses me with its magnitude—absorbs my time weighs down my Spirits—banishes all other subjects of importance to myself and my family from my thoughts and leaves me nothing to trifle about but my seedling trees. This day it disqualified me by weakness and indisposition— Elizabeth C. Adams and her brother Joseph H. were here towards evening— They had been to Medford to the wedding of Luther Angier yesterday— I received a Letter from Lieutenant T B Adams, dated at Fort Brook the 4th. of July— Much discontented.

div.p: 4. V. Thursday.

I find it necessary to pay some attention to the seedling plants in my boxes and Pots; but am again disappointed by losing the connection between the seeds sown and the plants that come up— The Pots are kept in the cellar through the winter and when I return home in the Summer I find the distinctive marks upon each of the Pots has disappeared

No appearance of vegetation upon some of them and several apple and Pear Seedlings
in others, but without indication of their kinds— William Spear was here this afternoon and I went with my Son Charles and him over the hill opposite my house to examine how it may be most advantageously laid out in Streets and house lots— Charles had also the purpose of selecting a spot, on which he purposes to build a dwelling house— Spear had seen Mr Humphrey of Weymouth, who promised to come over and make the survey next Wednesday. Elizabeth C. Adams and her brother Joseph were here early in the Evening. I was still occupied so much with reading that I wrote less than my daily task— The remarkable portions of Mr Madison’s life are—1. his agency relating to the abortive attempts to amend the Articles of Confederation— His influence in obtaining the cession by Virginia to the United States, of the Northwestern Territory. His exertions in originating and directing the movements which resulted in the adoption of the Constitution of the United States. 1. In the Legislature of Virginia— 2. In the Conventions of Annapolis and of Philadelphia— 3. In his contributions to the Federalist— 4. by his Speeches and influence in the Virginia State Convention which adopted the Constitution— His share in organizing the Government of the United States under the Constitution— Then his alienation from the administration of Washington, his associations with Jefferson, his variances with Hamilton— His favouring views of the French Revolution, and his opposition to the administration of my father— Then his career of 8 years as Secretary of State under Mr Jefferson— His first and second Presidential terms and his Policy of War and Peace— Lastly his retirement of twenty years diversified by his occasional correspondence; by his agricultural pursuits; by his Offices as a Trustee and Rector of the University of Virginia, and his participation in the Convention to revoise the Constitution of the Commonwealth— All this will require notice, and for much of it I am in no wise prepared.
5. V. Friday.

While I was in my garden this morning, John Kirke who now lives with my neighbour G. W. Beale came over and reminded me of some of his operations the last autumn, in transplanting my trees, which had escaped from my memory— Every one of the English Oaks, so flourishing at the Northern end of the Nursery, but which he transplanted thence is dead. Several of the large Elms are alive and promising— My three boxes at the West end of the Garden, and the one next the road, are stocked with rows of apple and pear seedlings, but they are perishing for want of rain— I therefore determine to water them once or twice a week, as well as the Pots in one of which Strawberries sown by me last Summer have come up, and apple and Pear seedlings in others, but from what seeds I have lost all my indications.— I perceived this day the difference in the first appearance of vegetation between the Shagbark and Pignut Hickory— The Pignut puts up a shorter stem, and opens two single leaves nearly round, which as they increase in size take the shape of a spade— The Shagbark stem shoots up a stem from three to four inches long and then opens two or three short stalks with three leaves hanging to each— They are all at first of a dark brown colour, which gradually changes to a pea-green— I have found one more seedling plum in the Seminary bed— Thomas Adams this day brought me my tax bill for the year— Our Cook Mary left us this morning without waiting to be paid her wages, upon some question of etiquette with our three man Servants touching the sawing of wood and drawing of water— She went off in the Stage to Boston— Charles went to Boston, accompanied by Joseph H. Adams, and returned home to dine— I received a Letter from my nephew, Lieutenant Thomas B. Adams dated the 4th of July East Florida Fort Brooke (Note that was the day before yesterday[)], and as a symptom of the condition of my memory stands recorded on the preceding page.
But I did this day receive a Letter from John Elmsley, dated Toronto, Upper Canada making some enquiries concerning the bequest of Ward Nicholas Boylston, to Mrs Elmsley his Sister, and mother to the writer of the Letter; and a very kind Letter, from Richard Rush informing me of his proposed departure next Monday for London upon the agency for recovering the Smithson bequest— My work upon the Eulogy was rather more industrious than for several days past, but still very unsatisfactory— This is the anniversary day of my embarkation for Russia, 1809— Twenty seven years.
6. IV. Saturday

Long morning in my garden, nursery and Seminary. I have been ten summers sowing the Seeds of fruit and forest trees; and have a great variety of seedlings of many kinds— Some at every stage of growth, from 1827 to the shoots of this Season— I cannot distinctly remember the age of the several trees which have survived the first and second winters and there is so great a diversity in the rapidity and slowness of growth of different trees, even of the same kind, that I have Pear and especially Apple trees six or seven years old, shorter than other shoots even of the present Season— Among the difficulties of raising trees I find that of giving them strait stems quite prominent—especially of all those which have little growth the first Season— The winter frost followed by the vernal thaw heaves up the roots and the winter snows bend down their stems, which if not straitened in the Spring become irretrievably bent and twisted— I attempted this morning to redress several crooked and twisted stems of peach and pear trees three or four years old— A seedling Pear tree in the Seminary, which last year grew more and with better promise than any other, and which this Season put forth leaves abundantly has been turning for weeks to a dark brown, and is now just dead— Almost every one of my seedling Pears of this year, are wholly blighted— While I was in my Garden Harvey Field came with the mortgage of the Brackett house, and Fowles note, which he proposed to assign to me but I was obliged to decline— He spoke to me again about purchasing the Birch wood standing upon my Verchild pasture, and proposed to me to plant it over with Mulberry trees, which I am to take into consideration— Charles paid the second Instalment of my twenty shares in the Quincy Stone bank, and brought me the receipt of Ibrahim Bartlett the Cashier, for which a certificate of Stock is here after to be delivered to me. We had afternoon visits from Mr William Lee, and Doctor Wily a Surgeon in the Navy— My writing was thus this day much abridged
7. V. Sunday

Mr Whitney preached the morning discourse from Proverbs 9.12 “If thou be wise, thou shalt be wise for thyself: but if thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear it”— I had heard the Sermon once, if not twice before. Mr Whitney understands Wisdom, as used in the Proverbs of Solomon to mean Religion— A preceding verse says that the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and the text teaches wisdom upon selfish considerations— Mr Whitney administered the communion, and gave notice, that at the next performance of the same rite, the first Sunday in October a collection would be made to defray the expenses for the year. In the afternoon Mr Lunt preached from 2. Peter 1.5 And beside this giving all diligence add to your faith virtue; and to virtue knowledge: 6. And to knowledge, temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience godliness; 7 And to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness, charity— The doctrine was, that to the formation of the Christian character the assemblage of all the virtues is necessary and the failure
of Christians to attain the perfection peculiar to the system was attributed to the practice of giving a disproportionate influence to some one of the virtues to the disparagement or the neglect of others— Notice was given that there would be a temperance meeting and Lecture next Tuesday Evening— I read the 8th. Sermon of the 8th. volume of Saurin, against hasty judgments concerning the ways of God— The subject would have been more interesting if it had been more generalized— All hasty judgments are vicious, and they are almost universal— Hasty judgments on the Providence of God can scarcely be formed by sincere believers in Christianity, or in Providence itself— There is then much argument in this Discourse to prove that which no reasonable man would deny— In the Evening I attended at the Universalist Meeting and heard a young man address the youthful part of his auditory from 1. John 2.14. “I have written unto you, young men, because ye are strong”— The comment of the preacher upon these words was not destitute of ingenuity liveliness or fluency, and the discourse was well adapted to the auditory— The besetting sins of youth were rebuked in terms sufficiently severe, without being offensive, and with due brevity to avoid tediousness— There was good attendance in numbers and chiefly of the working men The performance was over before the evening Bell— While I was absent, Mr Beale and his three daughters—Isaac H and Joseph H. Adams with their Sister Elizabeth, and Louisa C. Smith, and E. Price Greenleaf were here— Mrs Adams was quite unwell, and confined nearly the whole day to her chamber.
8. III:45. Monday.

Morning in my Garden Nursery and Seminary. My Seedling trees of this, and some even of the last year are suffering by the drought, and the Sun of this day, has I fear killed no small number of them— I gathered in the garden several fully ripe Strawberries, and currants from the seedling bush at the garden gate, and sowed them in Pot 3. filled with fresh earth; together with one old peach Stone, and six or seven cherry stones. I crushed the currants and Strawberries, to put their seeds in immediate contact with the Earth— The Jenneton Pears are ripe a week later than the last year, and are much smaller— My two Southern Oaks are just forming their leaves of the year— Mr Edward Everett, now Governor of the Commonwealth, and Mrs Everett paid us a morning visit; and he gave me a Volume of his Orations and Speeches, recently published— They are among the best ever delivered in this Country, and I think will stand the test of time.— The custom of delivering Orations, on public occasions was introduced into this Country by the Boston Massacre of 5. March 1770. of which there were thirteen delivered successively till 1783. in Boston Town meeting— The 4th. of July was then substituted for the yearly town Oration, and these have been continued till the present time. Other towns and cities have followed the example, and other occasions have been taken for the delivery of similar discourses till they have multiplied so that they now outnumber the days of the year— Of the thousands and tens of thousands of these Orations which teem in every part of this Country, there are perhaps not one hundred that will be remembered, alteri Seculo; and of them, at least one half have been or will be furnished by Edward Everett— He has largely contributed to raise the Standard of this Class of compositions, and his eloquence has been the basement story of his political fortune; as yet one of the most brilliant ever made in this union— Mr Crane called here again and now wishes to purchase half an acre of land for a house lot between the house of Samuel Curtis, and the old house in which my father was born— I promised to go to-morrow, or on Wednesday and have the ground surveyed.
I received from Mrs D. P. Madison, a Letter, with a summary statement by her brother of the principal events in the life of Mr Madison; but it contains little if any thing that I can use for the Eulogy which I am preparing.
9. IV:30. Tuesday.

Heavy and unexpected rain in the Night and this morning, which I hope will save some of my seedling trees— I wasted three hours of luxurious enjoyment this morning in looking at them, and trimming some of the trees which have from three to seven years growth— The nursery now is overcharged with a grove of them which must be thinned away. I find twenty Shagbark walnuts in the Nursery: all so much grown that they may henceforth defy Summer’s Sun and Winter’s frost, but most of them must be transplanted— My Son Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— After dinner I went to Penn’s valley, paying a visit on my way to Benjamin Bass— I left with him the Policy of Insurance upon his house, which has expired and which he is to get renewed, and he promised to call on me and settle with me for interest due upon his Note more than two years— I called upon Mr Crane who went with me and I measured by pacing the lot between Samuel Curtis’ House lot and the old house in which my father was born. 25 paces to 8 rods—31 paces to 10 Rods— There were 111 paces from the South corner of Curtis’s lot, to the North corner of Harvey Field’s— Adam Curtis Harvey Field and Mr Wild came up while I was measuring— Crane was undetermined whether to take a lot of five or of eight rods front, and I left it to him to determine for himself— Mr Wild wished to purchase a corner of my lot between his houselot and Joseph Crane’s and enquired what price I would ask for it— I referred it to Harvey Field and Curtis, but they declined naming a price, and I am to take it into further consideration— I rode with Harvey Field to the Bank where he went to attend a weekly meeting of the directors Thence I walked home, and met on my way Noah Curtis who paid me ten dollars for a year’s rent of goose pasture— My morning’s idling in the garden and my afternoons ramble upon business consumed the time so that I wrote not half so much as I ought—
10. IV. Wednesday

Mr Humphreys and Deacon William Spear came between 8 and 9 o’clock this morning, and I went with them and my Son Charles over the hill opposite my house and he staked out a lot 8 rods in front and between 15 and 16 deep, upon which he proposes next Summer to build a house— Mr Humphreys surveyed the whole length of my lot from North to South to lay out a road 27 feet wide and a cross road from East to West at the Southern end— Deacon Savile Mr Thomas Greenleaf, and Mr Pope came to us while we were surveying— John Toohey our Gardener carried the chain— After this was finished we went to Penn’s valley. Mr Humphrey measured first the distance from Samuel Curtis’s line to Harvey Fields and found it 35 rods and 5 links— He then measured 5 rods front and ten deep from Curtis’s line, for a house lot for Benjamin L Crane, which was staked out and of which I agreed to give him a Deed at the rate of 1500 dollars an Acre. The amount of the 50 rods is 468 dollars and 75 cents— Humphreys measured also the strip, between Crane’s lot on the East side of the road, and Wild’s of which he promised to make a plan by the latter end of next week; being so constantly engaged upon his business that he could not make it sooner We were out from nine till half past two O’Clock, and I came home so much wearied that I was disabled from writing all the remainder of the day; the consequence of which was that I spent the afternoon chiefly in my Garden and Nursery— Found a small white worm (Say’s Algeria Exitiosa) in one of my Peach trees— The shoot from my Wollaston Apple bud, inserted in July 1834. and first put forth in August 1835 is 27 inches long.
One of my seminary maples, the fifth in the row, is three feet tall; but the one at the corner which grew twenty inches last Summer, having been ripped at the top of the stem by the nightly dorbug, and stripd of most of its leaves by the same destroyer has been so much checked in its growth that it is now onlyinches high. The seedling Peach trees in the seminary are about nine feet high— I purpose to make one more experiment with the horseplum stones, though I think none of them that I have planted has ever yet vegetated
11. III.45. Thursday.

I rose so early that I was enabled to write some portion of Eulogy, though not to redeem my diary altogether— I took to certain logarithmic calculations which consumed some time and went into Boston with Charles and his wife— I was desirous of seeing Mr Nathaniel Curtis, but was disappointed. He was not to be found. Mr Armstrong the mayor of the city called at Charles’s Office, and spoke to me of the time and place, for the delivery of the Eulogy. I proposed to him a later day than we had contemplated finding as I do the want of longer preparation, and mentioned the second week in September, to which he foresaw no objection— He said that he should prefer the Old South Church; where he himself attended public worship as his father, and his grand-father had done before him; but the Singers who were to take part in the celebration preferred the Odeon, which was heretofore the Federal Street Theatre, and was said to be a Hall, more favourable to the voice. He said the choice should be entirely at my option, and I proposed to visit both the places, before fixing upon the one to be selected, to which he agreed— Isaac P. Davis came and told me that Mr Preston, the Senator of the United States from South Carolina, was in the City— I went to the Tremont house where he lodges; but they told me he was gone out with Mr Lawrence— I met there Coll. Josiah Quincy junr who told me that Mr Preston was going out to Quincy with his father to take tea with him to-morrow, and invited me to join the party— He said they would probably call upon me, on their way. I purchased some paper and three small children’s books for the little girls— We dined at Governor Edward Everetts at Charlestown—a family party—Mr Brooks—his Sons Peter C. and Gorham with his wife, Mr and Mrs N. L. Frothingham, together with a Mr and Mrs Chinn, from Lexington Kentucky and New-Orleans, Isaac P. Davis and John C. Gray, with us constituted the company— A plentiful, elegant and sumptuous dinner, the Cook of which, Mrs Neal told Mrs Everett that her mother had cooked my wedding dinner in London; but she was mistaken; it must have been my Sister’s marriage with Coll. William S. Smith— I had no opportunity for the conversation with the governor which I had desired; but thanked him for the Volume of his Speeches, and he asked me, if I could furnish a list of my own publications, which I told him I could easily do, though they are not worth the trouble of making it— We left Mr Everetts after six sat down Isaac P. Davis at his house at Boston, and got home just before eight.
12. IV. Friday.

I had rather a restless and almost sleepless Night, and Charles was unwell with a severe headache till towards Evening. I got entangled with logarithms, which swallowed up the morning till breakfast time— The garden and nursery, took again much of the morning; and the trimming of an English white Oak— I ventured also to trim a young Shagbark walnut tree— There is at the Northwest corner of the garden adjoining the old house in which my father was born, at the face of Penn’s Hill a Shagbark tree transplanted from my garden here by my brother, when he lived in the old house about 1811. and was from one of the nuts that I planted in 1804. The tree there is not more than half the size or height of the one in my garden, but it now bears nuts— These two trees alone have
survived of my plantation of October 1804— We had a morning visit from Dr Holbrook now at the age of 84 and enjoying good health; and in the afternoon, visits from Mr and Mrs Abbott Lawrence, and Mr Preston the Senator from South-Carolina— They were going to take tea at Coll Quincy’s, and I followed them there— With them were Miss Calhoun daughter of the other South-Carolina Senator, Miss Hampton a Mr King of the same State, a young man by the name of Stackpole, and Mr and Mrs Chinn— I gave Mr Preston the Letters that I have received fromMorse and Rembrandt Peale soliciting employment as Painters for the Rotundo at the Capitol— He said he had written to Mr Jarvis requesting him to meet him in Boston. He had seen Allston, but had come to no arrangement with him, and was to see him again— That he had seen Morse, and conversed with him not without painful embarrassment— That Chapman and Inman both objected to furnishing sketches as the Committee had required. So it is that mediocrity shelters itself under the dignity of Art; and thus it is that works at the cost of a Nation settle into patronage jobs— Most of the company left to return to Boston just after dark, but I remained an hour longer. Miss Quincy told me of a manuscript Journal belonging to Samuel Sewall, minister of Burlington—Middlesex County, a Congregational Church; which Journal was kept by Chief Justice Samuel Sewall who was born 28. March 1652 and died about 1730 In this Journal there is a very particular and minute account of the marriage of Daniel Quincy with Anna Shepard my ancestors, of which I had never been able to obtain any account and which took place at Mr Brattle’s house in Boston, and was marked by a painful occurrence of the sudden death of Mrs Brattle on the same Night; and there is in the same Journal a narrative of the death of Daniel Quincy and many other particulars relating to the Quincy family: of all which Mrs Susan Quincy has taken a copy; and she promised me a copy of all that relates to my ancestor Daniel Quincy— The Colonel walked home with me.
13. IV:30. Saturday.— My Son Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherines birthday—5.

Yesterday the first blossom opened upon one of the Althaea trees before my Library window Three days later than the last year, and nearly three weeks later than at one former year. I have hitherto found it impossible to raise Althaea’s from the seed— The first winter after their vegetation having invariably killed them— I have now two from seed in the Eastern seminary which being sheltered from the bleak North and Northwest winds may fare better— There is a very remarkable difference in the growth of trees, some of the same kinds throwing up one short shoot early in the Spring and then ceasing to grow the rest of the year others putting up two, and some three shoots in one Season, but at different times, and some growing the whole Summer from April to November— I have different Apple Seedlings exhibiting the three modes of vegetation— I lost much of this day in searching for old family Records of Daniel Quincy and Chief Justice Samuel Sewall I found at last a copy of a Letter from him to his Son of the same name written in the year 1720. and giving a short account of his birth, and of the first, and second emigration of his father from England to this Country— Charles went into Boston and returned to dine— I wrote after dinner until near Sunset, but with extreme difficulty— I become every day more sensible of the decays of my Memory— I see too what is more painful to realize, that the Memory cannot fail without a corresponding decline of the Judgment; and of the imagination.— I walked out this Evening as far as the 6th. mile-stone—
14. V. Sunday—

Mr Greenwood of Boston, preached for us this morning from Romans 11.36. “For of him, and through him, and to him are all things: to whom be glory for ever. Amen.” The doctrine which he deduced from the text was that the foundation of all morality was the will of God, and that
utility could be assumed as the basis of morals only so far as it was conformable to the Will of God— This was undoubtedly the Law and the Prophets of the Hebrews, and it is the genuine Law of Christianity— These Metaphysics are at this day applied more frequently to discussions of Politics than of religion—but for Government and for religion the foundation of duty, is one and the same—and it can be no other than the Will of God— This follows necessarily from two previous assumptions—first that there is a God the creator and ruler of the Universe—and secondly that man is accountable to him— If you admit a plurality of primary causes, or, more than one God, then the phenomena of the Universe proceed from more than one will, and morals must seek for another basis; the beauty of virtue, the fitness of things, utility, the moral sense, or the greatest good of the greatest number— You have the Stoic, the Epicurean and the Platonic theories.— The Christian theory is far more elevated— Under that dispensation the end of human existence is not the pursuit of happiness, but the performance of duty— The pursuit of happiness is in its nature a principle essentially selfish— The obligation of duty is essentially social— Now the fair and the good the καλον και αγαθον of Plato admits this, and it runs through all the discourses of Socrates— But all the Greek Philosophers including Socrates sought for the sources of human happiness in man himself— It was reserved to the Mosaic and Christian philosophy to trace them all to the sense of responsibility to the Creator— I invited Mr Greenwood to dine with us, but he was engaged to Mr Edward Miller. The afternoon Sermon was from Job 14.14. “If a man die, shall he live again?” upon the immortality of the Soul— Mr Greenwood’s turn of mind is argumentative, and his reasoning forcible; but his delivery is cold and sluggish— There was a light thunder shower, which overtook us before we reached home this afternoon. I read the ninth Sermon of the 8th. volume of Saurin; upon Pleasure; or as it is in the French idiom the Pleasures— The text is from Ecclesiastes 9.7.8.9. and the preacher considers them as ironical. This appears to me questionable to say the least— He declines giving his reason for his construction of the text, but assuming it as a severe censure upon the pursuit of Pleasure, enlarges upon it with a corresponding commentary— He complains that he is restrained from the application of his censure upon vice, to individuals by respect for persons and says that the ministers of the gospel dare not speak of the criminals among their auditories, and that he himself is afraid to charge sundry persons then present at his discourse— He disclaims all austerity of principle, and says that he does not pronounce the theatre, other public amusements or even play, evils in themselves; but blames them only for their enticements and tendencies to corruption. This Sermon is less edifying than others precisely because the Orator could not speake his whole mind. We had an evening visit from Coll. Josiah Quincy junr
15. V: Monday.

Mr Curtis came over this morning from Roxbury, and left with me a large file of papers relating to the Estate, and the Execution of the Will of the late Ward Nicholas Boylston. I read to him the Letter I have received from Mr John Elmsley enquiring about the legacy to Mrs Elmsley in her brother’s Will— This is of 150 pounds sterling to be paid from the proceeds of Lands in the Province of Nova-Scotia— A person named R M. Cutler Postmaster at Guysborough in that Province has been the agent of the Executors for the sale of the Estate. Mr Curtis had a Letter from him dated 18. Jany 1834, complaining of numerous intrusive settlers upon the Lands, and requiring to enable him to prosecute for the recovery of the Lands the original grant of them from the king, and the instruments of conveyance of them to Mr Boylston— The Lands were
granted by George the 3d. to Benjamin Hallowell, and by his Will, made at Boston in November 1796 were bequeathed to his three children, Admiral Hallowell, W. N. Boylston and Mrs Elmsley, as Tenants in Common— In 1826. Admiral Hallowell released his portion of the Lands, which are in the Township of Manchester and County of Sidney, to W. N. Boylston, as Mr and Mrs Elmsley had released theirs in April 1801. Mr Curtis had the deeds of Release; but neither the original grant nor Benjn Hallowells Will— Cutler’s Letter says he can in case of need obtain a copy of the grant from the Registry in the Province, and as the Will was made at Boston and Mr Hallowell had real Estate there I presume it must be recorded in the registry of Wills at the Probate Office there. Mr Curtis said he would enquire and if the record of the Will is there would obtain an authenticated extract of that part of it containing the bequest of the Nova Scotia Lands. He also left with me the Letters received since last Summer from Petty Vaughan, one of which announces a dividend of three shillings and six pence on the pound of William Vaughan’s Estate— He mentioned that Ward Nicholas Boylston was now of age, studying physic with Doctor Shattuck, and desirous of having a yearly allowance from his grandmother who thought of allowing him 450 dollars a year— The other brother is in a merchant’s store at Boston— Ward came of age last Wednesday— Mr Curtis shewed me a plan of new Streets to be laid out in Charlestown, including the Boylston lands, which are increasing in value, and he proposes to build upon one of the vacant houselots in Boston— I promised to see Mr Curtis again, after examining the papers that he left— This afternoon we were visited by Coll. M’Kenney of Philadelphia, with Mrs Baldwin and Mrs Dickson Ladies from New-Orleans each with a daughter— They went also to the burying ground, before which they are now building a solid wall— I gave Mr M’Kenney a Copy of the Oration upon La Fayette and of the Eulogy upon James Monroe— At dusk I walked to Mrs Ann Adams’s where I found Mr and Mrs Edward Miller and their daughter, and Mrs Phineas Foster with her daughter I agreed to call for Mrs Adams to-morrow, to attend the funeral of Mrs Loring at Hingham— My writing was this day abridged by the visitors.
16. V. Tuesday

Harvey Field and Samuel Copeland were successively here this morning— Field to request me to draught a Petition of sundry persons to the Town of Quincy to open a new road from the Railway Quarries to what is called the Captains Bridge: the principal object being to prevent by anticipation the opening of another road by order of the County Commissioners, and which it is apprehended would divert the travel away from Quincy and towards Randolph— Copeland brought the draught of a Petition made by Mr Francis Jackson which he wished me to take, and draught another in its stead. But his main purpose was to obtain my signature to head the petition— I saw no occasion for another draught, and after striking out some sentences which I thought superfluous I signed the Petition— After an early dinner I went with my Son, and took Mrs. Ann Adams with whom we went to Hingham and attended the funeral of Mrs Loring the last of the daughters of Coll. John Thaxter, and his wife Anna Quincy, the eldest daughter of my great Grandfather John Quincy— Mrs Loring was married I think in 1777. and was then about twenty years old— She died last Saturday at the age of 79. We reached the House at 3. O’Clock the time which we had heard was fixed for the funeral but it was an hour later— We went therefore to the house of the Revd. Mr Charles Brooks and saw him and his wife— She is in the
last Stage of a pulmonary consumption, and cannot live many weeks longer. She nevertheless came down to receive Mrs Adams, and exerted herself much to converse. Mrs John Greenleaf with her Son in Law Dawes came in and I went with Mrs Adams and visited Mr and Mrs Edward Thaxter, where we saw his father Mr Thomas Thaxter and their two daughters about 12 and 10 years of age— At 4. O’Clock we went to Mr Loring’s and attended the funeral— The Service was performed by Mr Brooks— Mr Quincy Thaxter, his Son Norton Quincy, his daughters Elizabeth and Anna, Mrs Tufts and her daughter Susan, Mrs Nehemiah Parsons with her daughter, and a few other relatives of the Thaxter family were present, and scarcely any one else— We went to the grave-yard on the Hill adjoining the Meeting House, and saw the Coffin deposited in its quiet receptacle— Most of the Relations returned to the house to tea, where Mrs Adams said we should be expected, and where Mrs Whittemore, the daughter of Mrs Loring had invited us— But I disinclined to funeral tea-parties, and preferred returning home— Here we found Elizabeth C. Adams and her brother Joseph afterwards came, and accompanied her home.
17. V. Wednesday.

Morning visit from President Quincy, who brought with him an Album of a young girl, Miss Pringle (Rosamond) daughter of James R. Pringle, Collector of the Customs at Charleston South Carolina— Mr Quincy had written a few lines of quotation from I know not whence, and I wrote two lines under them— The late Lieutenant Governor Winthrop, with Isaac P. Davis followed shortly after, and visited my garden and Nursery, where there are now a variety of seedlings interesting by the phenomena, of their growth. Then came the Revd. Dr Thomas Gray, with his Son in Law and Colleague Mr George Whitney, and in the Evening Mr Benjamin L. Crane, who came for the Deed of fifty Square rods of land for his house-lot adjoining upon that of Samuel Curtis— He had come once before on Monday Evening, and was quite disappointed at not finding the Deed executed for him— I had made the draught, but delayed executing the deed, waiting for the minutes of Mr Humphreys’s last Survey— He was however so anxious for his deed that I promised to execute, and deliver or send it to him to morrow Morning— I walked to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s and requested him to come, and take the acknowledgment of it to morrow morning. Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf were there— Isaac P. Davis told me that Mr Leonard Jarvis was now in Boston, and that Mr M’Kean was expected there this Evening; but that Mr Preston was to leave the City at four O’Clock this afternoon— Mr Nathaniel Curtis has sent me an authenticated copy of Mr Benjamin Hallowell’s Will, executed at Boston, in Novr. 1796. An original grant by Montague Wilmot, Governor of Nova-Scotia in April 1765 under an order of the king in council of 11. July 1764. on the East side of Chedabuctou Harbour, with a plan on the grant itself marking it as of 20000 acres—and an indenture of release and quit-claim from the Executors of Jonathan Sterns an Assignee of John Lodge, for a Tenement and farm of seven hundred acres, called Beachcroft, in the township of Manchester on the East-side of Milford Haven— I suppose a part of the Lands included in the grant—but further information is needed before I can answer Mr Elmsley’s Letter
18. IV. Thursday— My Son Charles’s birth-day—29.

Mr T. Greenleaf came this morning and took the acknowledgment of the Deed of fifty square rods of Land to Benjamin L Crane, for a house lot, adjoining that of Samuel Curtis, near the foot of Penn’s hill.
He and Mary witnessed the Execution of the Deed by me and by my wife to relinquish her dower— I went to the Quincy Stone bank, and opened an account there, by a deposit— Then went and delivered the Deed to Benjamin L. Crane, who paid me 468 dollars 75 Cents for fifty rods of Land, five Rods front, and ten Rods deep— I walked up Penn’s hill to the corner where I sold last fall half an acre to Lewis Bass, and found it remaining just as it was.— Thence, returning I called at Mrs. Ann Adams’s and left Letters from her Son Thomas the Lieutenant to her and to Joseph. She was gone with Mr and Mrs Coombs to Medford and Joseph with Isaac Hull, and Meade, to Cohasset— I stopped again at the Bank and deposited 470 dollars, and then returned home the morning being gone— Mr Aaron Clark an Alderman of the City of New York, brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr William L. Stone. He came with his daughter a Mr Huntington, and his daughter Mrs James. Their visit was merely of curiosity— Charles and his wife went into Boston, and dined with Mr and Mrs Gorham Brooks— They returned before dark in the Evening— Mary with the three little girls went to tea at Mrs Edward Miller’s— We change our bedchamber on account of the plastering of the new entry and passage way at the North-side of the House.
19. IV:30. Friday

I am obliged to use the long room below for my writing and reading, which is some discomposure to my arrangements— I gave Charles a check on the Quincy Stone Bank for 625 dollars payable to Elizabeth C. Adams, and he took up my two Notes to her of 1. Jany. 1831. and 7 April 1832—the amount of both being 3625 dollars, and returned them to me— A man by the name of Benjamin Kendall, who told me that he was born in the West-riding of Yorkshire in England, came to me upon a very strange errand— He had an old tattered English Newspaper of July 1822 containing an advertisement from a person named Leighton, that considerable property in America had been left to the right heirs of Francis Kendall, and urging them to report themselves to him— And now after fourteen years from the date of the advertisement he comes and declares himself one of those heirs, and applies for advice how to find the property and ascertain what it is— He told a long and incongruous story, in English such as I never heard before and had difficulty to understand; but finally said he had received a Letter from one of his family who informed him that the property was in Boston, and that the British Consul had the subject in charge— I advised him to apply to the British Consul at Boston, and if he should find that he knew nothing of the matter, then to the British Consul at New-York— He said he had applied to the Registry of Wills, at Boston, and at Cambridge to get a copy of the Will of Francis Kendall— That were two Wills executed by persons of that name at Boston, and thirteen at Cambridge— And of the latter, one will corresponded with that from which his expectations
and of this he had a copy, but not with him— He came to me as a member of Congress, supposing that body had some agency in the concern, which I assured him they had not.— A black woman also calling herself by the name of Emma Adams, came complaining of having been ill used, at the Boston house, in South-Boston; and said she had been referred to me to obtain redress.— After some explanation she found she was mistaken, and it was the Governor to whom she had been directed— I made small progress in my writing, but found it necessary to read the debates in the Virginia Convention upon the federal Constitution; and I answered an invitation from the Mayor and aldermen of Boston to attend the examination of the Public Schools next Tuesday and Wednesday and the dinner at Faneuil Hall, on Wednesday— I declined—
20. III 45. Saturday.

Henry Hardwick came this morning to enquire about the deed of the small strip of Salt-marsh land, which I sold him, at the Mount Wollaston farm— I had agreed to go this afternoon to measure it off, for a description to be inserted in the Deed; but he said Monday afternoon would be more convenient to him, and I agreed to go with him then— He paid me the fifty dollars for the land now— Harvey Field came to enquire whether I would take the five shares of the Quincy Bank Stock, of which he had before spoken to me; but I had not now the means.— Mrs Wales and Mrs Ann Beale paid visits to our Ladies. Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned to dine, and the Ladies went to Weymouth, and visited Mrs Tufts— Mrs Ann Adams, and her daughter Elizabeth were here a few minutes about Sunset— I made very little progress in my writing, but read the papers of Pacificus, and cursorily through, all the debates in the Virginia Convention, upon the federal Constitution. Useful occupation, but making no headway in my work— Paid my daily visitation to my plants. discovered one more pignut hickory just out of the ground— The Apple-seed, last up in Pot 2 last night cast off its shell which has been hanging five days like a cap on its seed leaves and they opened— Yesterday the last Jenneton pears were gathered from the high branches of the tree— Over ripe— I trimmed an English Oak at the bottom of the Nursery— The multitude of self-sown elms in the garden is so great that I trample on many of them inconsiderately— This was certainly a great bearing year for the trees, as the last autumn was of Ashseeds— They bear apparently in alternate years— I staked out in the Seminary two twigs of the Lombardy poplar, growing from an old stump—
21. V. Sunday.

Mr Lunt’s discourse of this morning was from Revelation 5.1. [“]And I saw in the right hand of him that sat on the throne a book written within and on the back side, sealed with seven Seals 2 And I saw a strong Angel proclaiming with a loud voice, Who is worthy to open the book; and to loose the Seals thereof?” this he said was the book of Fate— There is something mystical and mysterious in every part of the Book of Revelation, which Mr Lunt said was to be considered as the prophetical history of the Church of Christ, from the time when it was written to the end of the world. Of this I cannot help entertaining doubts— That it is prophetic I believe because it professes to be so; but after eighteen centuries of fulfilment no commentator has ever yet discovered its meaning, and it may be doubted whether it has contributed to promote the universal prevalence of Christianity,
or the reverse— In the afternoon Mr Lunt’s text was from Psalm 16.11. “Thou wilt shew me the path of Life: in thy presence is fulness of joy; at thy right hand there are pleasures forevermore.” The enjoyments of Religion, are a favourite topic with him, and he dwells upon them with an earnestness evincive of sincerity. Mr Degrand came out from Boston and dined with us— He brought intelligence that President Jackson in a Letter to Newton Cannon, Governor of Tennessee has countermanded the call of General Gaines for a thousand men from that State for a fraudulent and treacherous invasion of the Territory of Mexico— Degrand went to Meeting with me after dinner, and in the Evening took Mr Beale’s son George with him back to Boston. The Ladies with Charles this Evening visited at Coll. Quincy’s; and I walked to Mr Edward Miller’s— There I found Mr Beale and his daughters— Dr Woodward, Louisa C Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams, and afterwards Mrs Ann Adams.— I came home after the Evening bell— I read the tenth Sermon of the 8th Volume of Saurin; upon the observance of the solemn festivals, and particularly of the day of rest—(the Sabbath) The celebration of all festivals was abolished by the English Independents from whom our congregational churches are descended, and by the Presbyterian Church of Scotland. We have none of them the Episcopal English Church has retained many of them and the Lutheran Church several. The French Hugonots I believe celebrated Christmas, Easter and perhaps Whitsunday—but Saurin makes only a general reference to the festivals without specifying any one of them, and saying very little of the duty to observe them— But he complains with great severity of the disregard of the Sabbath by his own people and insists that they are more guilty in that respect than any other Christians of any age or denomination— In this as in almost all his discourses Saurin censures and rebukes his auditory with no sparing voice, and if they were as vicious as he represents them, the infidelity of the present age scarcely surpasses that of those days— A comparison of Saurin’s Sermons, with those of Massillon and Bourdaloue, and those of Tillotson, South and Barrow, will give much insight into the politics of the age in which they lived, as well as into the prevailing prejudices and passions of the conflicting nations of Europe at that time.
22. V. Monday.

The Nights are so cold that we have fires almost every morning and last night there was a light frost— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— He brought me out a volume, which Isaac P Davis found at the Athenaeum containing a pamphlet of nullification papers, among which is Mr Madisons report to the Legislature of Virginia in 1799: which was published by Jonathan Elliot in 1832— I was called from my garden to Mr I Evans who gave me tickets for my Son, and myself to his introductory Lecture, this Evening to a course of seven which he proposes to deliver during the next fortnight at the town Hall— He sat and conversed with me nearly two hours upon English Literature, and English Eloquence and Orators— At four O Clock this afternoon William Spear and E. Price Greenleaf came— We went down to the mount Wollaston farm—and met Henry Hardwick at the spot where I had agreed to convey to him a small strip of Salt marsh land— We measured it both within and without the fence, and found the first about 40 and the whole about 55 rods. We took the bearings by estimate, and I made minutes of the several measures, from which in the Evening I drew a plat of the land. Returning we stopped at the house now building which is to be completed in the course of the next month— I walked with Mr Greenleaf, round the orchard and seedling forest lot. The
appearance of the Orchard is discouraging, many of the Apple-trees set out in 1830 being dead, and none of those that survive being in a flourishing condition. But on three sides of the border there are at least five hundred Oak, Chesnut, and Shag bark walnut trees, from the Acorns and nuts which I sowed in October 1830. and which promise to make in twenty years from this time a thick grove of forest trees: On the Eastern side of the border, where the plantation of 1830. totally failed, but where Kirke last October sowed a large quantity of Shagbark Nuts, and Ash-seeds, great numbers, of both kinds of the trees are up and looking well, but not much grown because they are shaded by a thick growth of coarse and rank weeds from four to five feet high— The Earth was ploughed up there last fall, but has not been weeded this Summer— On the other sides of the border; and round the Apple-trees of the Orchard the ground is hard; and for the further growth of the trees the loosening of the soil is all that seems to be required. My Son Charles was with us, and I took his son John Quincy with me in the Carry all— But he became impatient while we were examining my Orchard forest, and I sent him home with Spear. We returned after Sunset, and found Mrs Ann Adams and Louisa C Smith here— Elizabeth had dined with us. In the Evening I went with Charles to the Town Hall, and attended Mr Evans’s gratuitous introductory Lecture, upon sacred geography, and sundry and various other subjects. The next Lecture is to be to-morrow— The Hall was excessively crowded and the heat was intense— The Lecture occupied about an hour, and with the evening bell we came home— The company was gone.
23. V. Tuesday.

Mr Humphrey brought me a plan of the lots which he measured for me on the 10th. of this month; that which I sold to Benjamin L Crane, and that which Mr Wild proposes to purchase— Humphrey had just returned from measuring a continuation through Isaac Bass’s Land of the road which I intend to open over the Hill, and which Bass wishes to carry through to the other Street.— A person by the name of David Thayer of Braintree came to enquire of me what were the duties of a Chaplain on board our Ships of War. I informed him as far as I was able; but advised him to apply to the Navy Agent at Boston, or to the Commandant of the Navy yard at Charlestown, for further information— I asked him if he wished to obtain an appointment as Chaplain himself. He said he had not such a determinate design, but that the thought had occurred to him— I enquired if he was a clergyman; or had studied divinity— He said no; he had not received a learned education; but had lately applied himself to theological studies— He asked if there was not a teacher of Mathematics attached to our Vessels of War— I thought there was, to some of them and enquired whether he thought himself qualified for that office; he said he did not; but that he might become so— These visitors occupied part of the morning, and Mr E Price Greenleaf came and looked at the buds which he inserted in my cherry trees the 28th of last month. Most of them look well, but he advises to keep the cotton yarn bandages round them through the winter— The second bud of the Wollaston Apple inserted in July 1834. continues to shew an appearance of vegetation, and the bud which came out about this time last year continues to shoot up and promises to form a sound stem— The hazel-bush patch contains almost all my seedlings of the present year; and yields me opportunities for numberless observations very amusing when made, but immediately afterwards forgotten, and without useful result— My wife, Charles and his wife and myself went to a tea party at Coll. Josiah Quincy junrs.—Mrs President Quincy and her daughter Anna were there—Mrs R. G. Shaw and her daughter from Savin hill—Thomas and Daniel Greenleaf and their families, Mr Whitney and his son Augustus, Mr Lunt and Mrs Mr and Mrs Edward Miller and their daughter, Mr Beale and his daughters, and some other residents at Quincy were there— Mrs Quincy gave me a Letter from Miss
Eliza Susan Quincy, enclosing the extracts which she had promised me, from the Journal of Chief Justice Samuel Sewall— From these it appears that Daniel Quincy my ancestor was married to Anna Shepard on the 9th of November 1682. at the House of Captn Brattle at Boston, and that Mrs Brattle died suddenly that same night—and that Daniel Quincy himself died on the Sabbath day 10. August 1690.— By the Braintree town Records it appears he was born 12. Septr 1650— He married therefore at 32. and died at 40 years of age Several very affecting circumstances are related in the Journal, concerning his sickness and death, and judge Sewall speaks with much affection and respect of his character

Resumed last Night our bed chamber, and wrote again in my library— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine Josiah Adams was here, and paid me for a year’s rent of the pasture which he and his brother have hired of me several years— It is now from the first of last April leased to Harvey Field, with whom Mr Adams is not well satisfied— Josiah Adams is now 73 years of age—his brother Ebenezer is 75. they have passed their lives on the paternal spot where their and my great grandfather Joseph Adams the younger, dwelt, and where he died on the 12th. of February 1737. at the age of 82. having been born 24. December 1655— He married Hannah Bass, daughter of John and Ruth Bass, the daughter of John Alden— Hannah was the second wife of Joseph Adams; was born 28. Jany 1662. and died 24 Oct. 1705—their eldest son was Joseph the Minister at Newington—their second Son, my grandfather John, born 28. January 1691. and their youngest Son, Ebenezer, born 30. December 1704— His son Ebenezer bornMarch 1737 was the father of the present Ebenezer and Josiah— They are of the fourth generation possessors of the paternal Estate descended to them from the youngest Son; and they have held it all their lives in common—they both married Sisters of the Minister Peter Whitney, for their second wives, and they are in character; capacity and condition in life, exact representations of the first Henry Adams, the founder of the family in this Country, and of his youngest son, the first Joseph born in England in 1626 and who died in 1694— Josiah is now somewhat broken, and complained much of suffering with the rhumatism— He lingered with me at least two hours, talking of granite quarries, woodlands, railways, and his uncle Zabdiel Adams heretofore Minister of Lunenburg, of whom he told me many amusing anecdotes— He detained me so long that I had little time left for my garden excursions— There I found to observe, only one new risen shagbark walnut and filled a Pot, with a Quincy Plumstone, and several Jenneton Pear cores and seeds— Transplanted into Box 1. S.W. Garden two seedling Pears of the present year— Afternoon and part of the Evening devoted to writing.
25. V. Thursday.

Mr Jason Houghton Collector of the taxes at Milton brought me three tax-bills, one for County and town, and two for School district, all amounting to one dollar and 19 cents and all assessed upon my lot of 2 1/2 Acres of Saltmarsh land at Penny-ferry. The school-tax is a new one— There was at 11. O’Clock this morning a Meeting at my house of the Supervisors of the Temple and School-fund— Present—Messrs. Greenleaf, Beale, and Miller and my Son Charles as Clerk— Mr Quincy was absent— The agent Jewett was re-elected for the present year, and Committees were appointed to lay out the lots and the road through the ground, and to contract for leasing the house lots at certain fixed prices, for each lot, below which they are not to be leased at all— Also for examining the Treasurer’s accounts, and reporting respecting the other lots given by my father to
the Town— The meeting was dissolved about half past 12. and I went with Charles and his wife into Boston to dine at Mr Frothingham’s. As we got into town about an hour before dinner time, I went and visited the annual exhibition of Pictures at the Athenaeum— It is this year very meagre and scanty— A few pieces by Fisher, Doughty and Chapman have some interest— Chapman’s are views of Washington’s birth place—of his mother’s house,—of the bed chamber where he died, and of his tomb; all very plain and unpicturesque places— After wearing away an hour at this inspection where I met General William H. Sumner, I went and dined at Mr Frothingham’s. Mr Peter E. Brooks, and his Sons Edward and Gorham were there— Mr Frothingham had some books of new German classical Literature, and lent me the first volume of Benjn Constant’s work upon religion— We came home just at dark, and found Joseph H. Adams here waiting for his Sister Elizabeth who had gone into Boston, and returned with us. They went in to spend the Evening at Mr Beale’s, and Mary with them.
26. IV. Friday.

Joseph H. Adams came this morning; and with him and my Son Charles, about noon I bathed, and swam about five minutes at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf— The first time this Season that there has been any invitation in the weather, and even now we found the water icy-cold. I had the hearth in our dining room repaired and prepared for autumnal fires. I should have written much, and wrote but little—but found at the Office,—Wirts Life of Patrick Henry, and Yatess minutes of the debates in the federal convention of 1787. which furnished much reading in elucidation of the life of James Madison— The garden is a perpetual temptation to me to stray; and although I intend to allow to it no more time than is necessary for bodily exercise, three and four hours of every morning are absorbed insensibly to myself in mere inspection and observation of seedling trees from nine years to one week old. Those of the first season, require the most constant attendance; but those of former years are now susceptible of much remark— Among the most interesting are the maples of which I brought the seed from Philadelphia in May 1835 and of which I have now one in my Seminary, four feet high— I headed down this morning an English Oak in the seminary transplanted from the Nursery last October— It died down to the ground in the winter, and has thrown up several thrifty shoots— The English white Oak is of exceedingly rapid growth but is repugnant to transplantation— I find similar difficulties with the chesnut. The Horse chesnut the Willow, and the Button are more difficult to extirpate than to raise— The phenomena of the pear are perplexing.
27. IV. Saturday.

Charles went this morning into Boston, and returned to dine— I spent less time than usual in my Garden; but found in Box N 1. a seedling Ash which was growing thriftily till with these two days—but observing now that it was turning yellow, I took hold of it, and found it loose in the ground—on plucking it up I found the root of it was ripped off about an inch below the surface— Hundreds, perhaps thousands of apple, and especially of pear seedlings, perish in the same manner— I have a strong suspicion that they are thus eaten off by ants, for I remember not to have seen this destruction but in the vicinity of a subterraneous Ants nest— I replanted the Ash with its half inch of root, but without hope of saving it— My Bartlett pear tree bed was weeded, and is now covered with seedlings of this year from the last Fall plantation, with many self sown Elms. But of the six or seven rows first sown, that is in August and September, scarcely any have come up— Of those planted in October, and the beginning of November few have failed. The corner seminary Shagbark has been bitten by a frost, and its vegetation is totally stopped— A second leaf fully developed
from the plumelet of the seedling up in Pot 2. proves to be a seed from a brown bury pear sown the 25th. of last October.— A discovery!— I appropriated a vacant round patch in the Seminary to Mary Louisa, and she sowed there, Peach and Plum Stones— Apple and grape seeds.— Almost every one of the round patches in the garden and seminary now have seedling trees in them— Most of them several, and of various kinds of trees— That in front of my Library window, has a fine seedling Apple sown in 1833 and nowinches high— It has also two dubious Peach trees, 6 or 7. puny pears, and two wild cherries all of which must be taken up—
28. IV. Sunday.

Mr Newell of Cambridge preached this morning from Hebrews 12.1. “Wherefore, seeing we who are compassed about, with so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us.”— His afternoon Sermon was from 2. Corinthians 13.5. “Examine yourselves”— Mr Newell is a young man Minister of the Congregation at Cambridge, where Dr Holmes and before him Mr Hilliard were settled.— He was on the Committee for the examination of the Library with me, on the 15th. of last Month— His discourses are sensible and moral, but neither brilliant nor profound. The theological school at Cambridge, is yearly producing several such clergymen, and they are introducing a uniformity of composition and delivery, superior to those of their predecessors of the last age, but which leaves a desire for more variety at least of manner— Mr Newell dined with us, and is a person of modest, unassuming and gentle manners— The weather was at Summer heat, for the first time since I arrived from Philadelphia— Fahrenheit in the middle of the day about 90— I read the 11th. Sermon of the 8th. Volume of Saurin, upon the dispositions suitable to attendance on public worship the first of three—but by a blunder of the book binder, the pages 437. 438 and 441. 442. of the Volume are missing, and the corresponding pages of the 9th. Volume, are bound up in the 8th. and occupy their place. The pages of the 9th. Volume are not missing from their own place, but those missing from the 8th. volume are not there— The missing 437th. page of the 8th. volume is the close of the first Sermon upon the dispositions for attendance on public worship; and the 438th. is the beginning of the second on the same subject. these therefore I lose, as also the part of the second Discourse contained in pages 441. and 442. The third of the same Sermons is also a fragment in the book, with a note that the closing part of it had not been found among the author’s papers— They are very good Sermons, and very proper to be carefully read by attendants upon public worship at this day— They are like most of this preacher’s discourses severely reproachful to his own auditory, though towards the close, he sooths them by acknowledgements that it had been thought to have been observed, and assurances had been given, that within the last preceding ten years there had been a considerable improvement in their morals, and in their opinions—particularly in their charity towards the doctrines of their preachers— He says that they complain, perhaps with reason if a Sermon exceeds an hour in length—but that they do tolerate the doctrine that good works are essential to Salvation, and do not absolutely charge a Minister with inclining to Popery and auricular confession, even if he is anxious in his particular attendance upon the dying, and specific rather than general in his exhortations to them— Augustus Whitney was here this Evening
29. V. Monday.

Henry Hardwick was here this morning, about the deed for the Salt-marsh land that I have sold to him— He agreed to give fifteen dollars more for the enlarged boundary— Joseph H Adams came with Mr de Wint’s son John P. who is placed at Mr Angier’s school, and is now at Mrs T. B. Adams, during the vacation of Commencement. He staid and dined with us— Mr and Mrs Gorham Brooks paid us an afternoon visit and took tea here— They are to return to Baltimore by the first of October— Mr Thomas Greenleaf and his daughter were here in the Evening— They had been to Boston. Mr Greenleaf brought me a message from Mr Armstrong the Mayor, requesting me to fix a day for the delivery of the Eulogy on Mr Madison— This is rather embarrassing, as I do not see the end of my work and have yet much to write, and more to revise— I have come now to Mr Madison’s course of conduct relating to the alien and Sedition acts; a subject of extreme difficulty to manage, inasmuch as it forms in the opinion of his party friends, perhaps the greatest of his merits and services; while I myself believe him to have been in error throughout the whole of those transactions.— To refresh my memory on these subjects and to retrace the history of those controversies more accurately I read over the portion of Jefferson’s correspondence during that period published by his Grandson— It shews his craft and duplicity in very glaring colours— I incline to the opinion that he was not altogether conscious of his own insincerity, and deceived himself as well as others— His success through a long life, and especially from his entrance upon the Office of Secretary of State under Washington, until he reached the Presidential chair, seems to my imperfect vision a slur upon the moral government of the world— His rivalry with Hamilton was unprincipled on both sides— His treatment of my father was double dealing, treacherous and false beyond all toleration— His Letter to Mazzei and his subsequent explanations of it and apologies for it, shew that he treated Washington, as far as he dared no better than he did my father—but it was Washington’s popularity that he never dared to encounter— His correspondence now published proves how he dreaded and detested it— His letter to my father at the first competition between them for the Presidency— The fawning, dissimulation of his first address as Vice-President to the Senate, with his secret machinations against him from that day forth, shew a character in no wise amiable or fair; but his attachment to those of his friends whom he could make useful to himself was thorough-going and exemplary— Madison moderated some of his excesses, and refrained from following him into others— He was in truth a greater, and a far more estimable man.
30 III:30. Tuesday.

There was some rain, in the night and this morning, but not enough to moisten the earth which is exceedingly dry— I do not yet tire of visiting my seedling trees, and this day found two pignut hickories just out of the ground— I emptied a Pot in which I had last Summer sown, several Cores of the Jenneton Pear. I found several of them almost falling into dust; but without sign of vegetation— The trees that bear the Jargonelles and the Catherine Pears are hollow, and it is useless to sow seeds from them— The Plumelet of the brown bury, puts out the promise of a third leaf, and my potted seedling Strawberry sown last year puts out a creeper. I found palmer worms and hairy caterpillers upon a black walnut and upon an Apple seedling— The Jargonelles are all gathered, and the Catherines over ripe— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Elizabeth C. Adams, and John P. De Wint junr. dined with us, and Joseph H. Adams came for his Sister this Evening. The weather
cleared away in the course of the day—the atmosphere cool and at night cold I wrote little, and continued reading the Letters of Jefferson, from 1793 till August 1803. published by his Grandson— His duplicity sinks deeper and deeper into my mind— His hatred of Hamilton was unbounded— Of John Marshall most intense—of my father, tempered with compunctious visitings, always controuled by his ambition— They had been cordial friends, and co-operators in the great cause of Independence; and as joint Commissioners abroad after the Peace of 1783. there had then been a warm and confidential intimacy between them, which he never entirely shook off, but which he sacrificed always to his ambition, and at the last stage of his life to his envy and his poverty—for he died insolvent, and on the very day of his death received eleemosinary donations from the charity of some of those whom he had most deeply injured— This circumstance is not creditable to his Country— She ought not to have suffered a man who had served her as he had to die, with his household wanting the necessaries of life— But it was the natural consequence of the niggardly doctrines which his political system had imposed upon him, and which he had passed off upon the Country for Patriotism— Among his slanders upon the administration of my father was the charge of extravagance in diplomatic expenditure; and when he sent Mr Monroe on the Louisiana mission to France, he wrote to him that he could not have an outfit; and that the refusal of outfits was one of his reforms upon extraordinary missions— The end of all which was that Mr Monroe obtained not only the outfit, but gratuities and allowances more than any other minister abroad has ever had, and died leaving still unsatisfied claims— I am compelled to draw many other harsh conclusions against this great man, from his now published Letters
31. V. Wednesday— Commencement day at Cambridge

Mr William Spear was here this morning, and I agreed to go with him to-morrow afternoon, to meet Harvey Field at the Verchild pasture— I had promised to go yesterday afternoon but forgot the engagement. My wife, Mary and Charles’s wife went into Boston to return sundry visits, and came back to dinner, and Elizabeth C Adams dined with us.— With Charles I walked home with her—we found Louisa C. Smith there alone— We called at Mr John Greenleaf’s, but the house was dark and we could rouse no part of the family to receive us— There was a cry of fire at Milton, and the tocsin sounded to which our bell answered with an echo— The engines went part of the way, but learning that the fire was extinguished, returned without reaching the place— I set apart two seedling circles in the Seminary for my Granddaughters Georgiana Frances and Louisa Catherine, each with a Stake and stone bearing their respective names and in which they planted peach and plumstones; and apple and grape seeds— They take a fancy to this themselves, and I wish to encourage them in it— Simple and innocent pleasures, are not only enjoyments but virtues— An interest in the Life of Plants is more rational than in that of cats, dogs, Parrots or monkies and by its capability of being made useful deserves to be cherished, and cultivated— I had the natural taste for raising plants from the seed even
in my childhood, but the course of my life has not indulged me with its gratification— The shagbark walnut tree close to the Summerhouse cellar in the garden, the nut of which was planted by me in October 1804. is the earliest of my seedling plants— It is a large tree upwards of thirty feet high, and is now well loaded with fruit— But it requires twenty years for a result in plantation— It cannot therefore be assumed at too early a period of life, nor pursued withe effect unless by persevering continuance— For profit or for pleasure there appears to me to be no species of agriculture so commendable for a young man to devote himself, as the raising of trees, forest and fruit, from the seed— It is doubtless not equally suitable for females; yet the taste for planting if formed in childhood may contribute much to their comfort in life, and I wish to foster its first appearance in these children.—

Day— It has been like that of the last month after my arrival here; with the exception of the sleep after dinner which the coolness almost uniform of the weather has rendered unnecessary. Instead of it, I stroll round my garden and seminary usually for about an hour.— The preparation for the Eulogy of Mr Madison occupies my time with much reading, and my progress in writing upon it is slow and very irksome— There are circumstances in the Life of Mr Madison, of which I cannot speak with praise, and of which I would therefore gladly not speak at-all— But I cannot pass them over in silence.— Nor will it be possible for me to treat them without giving offence to a large portion of the People of this Union— Should I suppress the truth?
